body.p: Born on September 8, 1828 in Salisbury, North Carolina. Riverboat captain. Married Frances Littrell on April 28, 1852 and had eight children, including Mary Stratton, Nelson L., Pink Varble Jr., and Melvin. Lived in Oldham County until 1842, when he moved to Louisville. He drove a wood wagon for J.M Collins for three months. Became a riverman under Eli Vansickle. Opened a coal yard for J.H Mulford of New Orleans in Vicksburg, Mississippi in 1851. Elected by the city council of Louisville to the office of Falls pilot in September, 1853. In 1861 he transported fifty street cars to New Orleans (first used in that city) on barges, having to get permission from the Secretary of War. Appointed captain of flag ship "Diana" which moved Nelson's division of army from Louisville to Nashville, Tenn. After the fall of Fort Donelson he was appointed in command of the river, to go to Vicksburg to bring back the sick and wounded soldiers. Capt. Varble owned one-eighth interest in Louisville and Jeffersonville Perry Company, and had also $90,000 interest in the Champion Saw Mill in Louisville.
